coredata.dc:title: Analysis of EXAFS data of multiphasic heterogeneous catalysts
coredata.dc:creator: Sankar, G.
Vasudevan, S.
Rao, C.N.R.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
Cu K-edge EXAFS spectra of Cu-Ni/Al2O3 and Cu-ZnO catalysts, both of which contain more than one Cu species, have been analysed making use of an additive relation for the EXAFS function. The analysis, which also makes use of residual spectra for identifying the species, shows good agreement between experimental and calculated spectra.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 127, number 6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 4 July 1986 ANALYSIS OF EXAFS DATA OF MULTIPHASIC HETEROGENEOUS CATALYSTS G. SANKAR, S. VASUDEVAN and C.N.R. RAO 1 Solid State and Structural Chemistry Unit and Department of Inorganic and Physical Chemistry, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore 560012, India Received 10 March 1986; in final form 7 April 1986 Cu K-edge EXAFS spectra of Cu-Ni/Al^Oj and Cu-ZnO catalysts, both of which contain more than one Cu species, have been analysed making use of an additive relation for the EXAFS function. The analysis, which also makes use of residual spectra for identifying the species, shows good agreement between experimental and calculated spectra. 1. Introduction Extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) has been employed extensively to investigate structures of heterogeneous catalysts [1 3]. One of the serious problems in the analysis of EXAFS data of heteroge- neous catalysts arises from the presence of more than one type of back-scattering atom, leading to overlap- ping features. This may be due to the existence of two or more phases or to the presence of more than one type of atom in the same coordination shell surround- ing the central absorbing atom. Sinfelt and co-workers [3] have analysed the EXAFS of bimetallic Os-Cu/SiO^ catalysts, where both Os and Cu are present in the first coordination shell by making use of an additivity rela- tionship of the EXAFS function, x(fc); X(k)A=x(k)^+x(k^, (1) where the superscript refers to the absorbing atom and the subscript to the back scatterer. Van Zon et al. [4] referred to the problem of analysis of EXAFS of multi- phasic systems and suggest that the criteria for the re- liability of the parameters should be based on a com- parison of the experimental and calculated Fourier transforms (the imaginary part as well as the magni- tude). We considered it desirable to carry out a system- atic investigation of the various problems involved in * Contribution No. 355 from the Solid State and Structural Chemistry Unit. ' To whom all correspondence should be addressed. the analysis of EXAFS data of multiphase systems. In multiphasic catalyst systems, the absorbing atom is gen erally present in the form of different chemical species (e.g. a metal in the form of metal clusters and metal oxides). If we assume the additivity relation to hold strictly in such a multiphasic system, the EXAFS func- tion can be written as x(k)A =x^x(k\ ^x^x(k)y +x^x(k\ + ..., (2) where x^ is the relative concentration (EJC, = 1) of the ;th phase, the superscript refers to the absorbing atom and the subscripts, x,y,z refer to different backscat- terers. Many workers keep the concentration of dif- ferent species, Xj, constant and adjust the coordination number N., and this may lead to unrealistic N. values; furthermore, chemically it makes no sense to assume the relative concentration of different species to be constant, as we know from independent studies that this is not the case. It therefore seems more reasonable to vary JC; and employ reasonable N. values. We have considered the conditions which would necessitate a multiphasic analysis and have examined the applicabili- ty and limitations of additive relations such as eq. (2). For this purpose, we have investigated bimetallic Cu- 'NilAl-^0^ as well as Cu-ZnO systems, both of which contain more than one active species of copper. While a careful inspection of the radial structure functions alone may suggest the need for a multiphasic analysis in certain instances, we have employed residual spectra as well as the additivity of individual contributions to the EXAPS function as useful criteria in establishing 620 0 009-2614/86/S 03.50 Elsevier Science Publishers B.V. (North-Holland Physics Publishing Division) Volume 127, number 6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 4 July 1986 the nature of the species in these catalysts. The present study has been most instructive and has enabled us to analyse EXAFS of reduced bimetallic Cu Ni/Al^O^ catalysts successfully. Similarly, in the case of reduced Cu-ZnO catalysts, where more than two copper spe- cies are present, the additivity relationship of the EXAFS function helps in determining the phases and the appropriate structural parameters. (4) N, is number of nearest neighbours of the /th shell, R, is the distance between the absorber atom and back- scatterer atom, a. is the Debye-Waller term. F.(k) is the amplitude due to the back scatterer and 6,(k) is the phase shift due to the back scatterer. Information about the individual coordination shells was obtained from the Fourier transform of the EXAFS function which yields the radial structure function, 0^(/?): 2. Experimental Catalyst samples were prepared by the impregna- tion of7-Al203 (200 m2/g) with aqueous solutions ofCu(N03)2 and ?(N03)2. The samples were dried and calcined at 600 C for 8 h followed by reduction in flowing hydrogen at 500 C for 6 h. The total metal loading on J-Al^Oy was 5 wt% for all the samples. Bi- metallic Cu Ni catalyst samples with the copper to nickel ratio 75:25, 50:50, 25:75 were prepared along with samples containing only Cu and Ni. Coprecipitat- ed Cu-ZnO catalyst (33-67 at%) was prepared follow- ing the method of Herman et al. [5]. The catalyst was calcined at 300 C and reduced at 250 C in flowing hydrogen for 5 h. Cu K-edge EXAFS spectra were recorded on a bent crystal spectrograph, the analyser being 201 planes of a mica crystal. The experimental arrangement has been described [6]. A rotating anode X-ray generator (GX- 18, Marconi Avionics Ltd., UK) with a copper target was used as the source of radiation. We were able to record EXAFS data upto 500 eV. Care was taken not to expose the reduced samples to air during the experi- ment. 3. Analysis of EXAFS data The EXAFS data were analysed in the single scat- tering approximation [7] where the EXAFS function is related to the structural parameters by XW = E (N./Rb) F,(k) exp(-2ah2) AV-^ * ' v,/", / ' ' Xsm[2Rk+28^k)], where (3) max V/?) = (-27r)-1/2 f k" x(k) exp(2i/y?) dA:. (5) The EXAFS function defined by X(k) =(ji- ^0)^0 (6) was extracted from the experimental data by the usual procedure [8] of subtracting a smoothly varying back- ground value obtained by a cubic spline fit over the entire k range. The data were normalized with respect to the step height obtained by extrapolating the back- ground value. The Fourier transform was performed over the k range a" 3.5 to 11.0 A"1 using n = 1 in the fc" weighting term. We find that higher values ofn tend to suppress features due to low-Z scatterers at low R values in the Fourier transform and enhance the noise in the high-fc region. A qualitative idea of the species present is obtained by inspection o{<f>^(R) which is then windowed in the region of interest and back transformed into fe-space. In the event of the windowed region of the radial struc- ture function having a single well defined peak, the in- verse transform would contain information essentially from a single shell. In most catalysts, however, the presence of more than one phase leads to overlapping features in the radial structure function and consequent- ly the inverse transform would have contribution from more than one shell (phase). In EXAFS data analysis, the parameters N.,R. and o, were obtained by fitting the inverse transform with the calculated EXAFS using an iterative non-linear least-squares procedure. The phase and amplitude functions were transferred from the model compounds. In cases where more than one phase was present, the additive expression given by eq. (2) was employed, keeping the concentration term, ;< ,., as a parameter in the non-linear least-squares proce- 621 Volume 127, number 6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 4 July 1986 dure. Comparing eqs. (2) and (3), we see that the role ofx. and N. are complementary; consequently, we have employed fixed N1 values (as obtained in the model compounds). 4. Results and discussion 4.1. Cu-Ni/Al^Oy catalysts Fourier transforms of the Cu K-edge EXAFS of re- duced CuSO NiSO/Al^C^ catalysts is shown in fig. la. The main peak at ^2.2 A is asymmetric, suggesting overlapping features due to multiphase or multishell contributions. In order to ascertain whether the fea- ture was genuine and not an artifact, we have examined the variation in the position of the peak (^2.2 A in fig. la) as a function ofEy for various values of n in the k" weighting term in eq. (5). Steams [9] has suggested that the asymmetry may be a consequence of the par- ticular value of 'o chosen for the analysis and has found that in materials containing elements with Z < 51 there is a unique value of EQ(E^) at which the asym- metry disappears. The value of .fig was obtained by plotting the peak position in the radial structure func- tion against "0 f01 different values of n in the k" weighting term [9]; the various plots pass through a crossover point at Ey The existence of such a cross- over point was used to distinguish between genuine features and artifacts due to low signal-to-noise ratio, glitches, etc. In the reduced Cu Ni/Al^C^ catalysts studied by us we do not find a unique crossover point; moreover, asymmetry exists for different values of 'o and for all values ofn and the asymmetry (of the 2.2 A peak in fig. la) was therefore considered to arise from the presence of more than one phase (shell). Analysis of the Cu K-edge EXAFS of the reduced Cu50 Ni50/Al203 catalyst was initially carried out assuming that a single copper species was present. The species was taken to be CuO in an environment similar to that in Cu metal. The calculated inverse transform using the phase and amplitude parameters of Cu metal and the experimental EXAFS are shown in fig. Ib. It was not possible to distinguish between near-neighbour copper or nickel atoms, since the phase and amplitude functions are expected to be quite similar. This was confirmed by calculating the phase and amplitude functions of Cu Cu and Cu-Ni atom pairs from the theoretical values given by Teo and Lee [10]. The identity of the second phase was obtained by taking the difference between the experimental and calculated (using a single Cu phase) inverse transforms. The resid- ual spectrum was Fourier transformed (fig. Ic), win- dowed and then back transformed to k space (fig. Id); the envelope of the back transform is clearly that of a low-Z scatterer, in this case, oxygen. In the case of Cu/Al^O^ catalyst, it has been suggested [11] that Cu metal and Cu^O are the main copper species. We car- ried out a two-phase analysis using eq. (2) with the phase and amplitude parameters of Cu metal and Cu^O. The calculated EXAFS function using the two- phase model shows far superior agreement with the experiment (fig. Ie) compared to the single-phase model (fig. Ib). A comparison of the calculated and experimental Fourier transforms also shows better agreement with the two-phase model (fig. If). We found good agreement between the calculated inverse transform of the two-phase model and the ex- perimental Cu K-edge EXAFS for all compositions of the reduced bimetallic Cu Ni/Al^G^ catalysts, as shown in fig. 2. We analysed the Ni K-edge EXAFS of the reduced Cu Ni/Al^O^ catalysts employing a multiphase model using the Ni-Ni scattering parameters of Ni metal and the parameters ofNi-0 in NiAl^O^. We have obtained good fits between the calculated and experimental data when the Ni content is low (<25%) and high (>75%). We are now carrying out a detailed analysis of the entire composition range. 4.2. Cu-ZnO catalyst The Cu K-edge EXAFS of the methanol synthesis catalyst Cu-ZnO was analysed following the procedure for multiphasic systems described earlier. Earlier stud- ies using XPS [12], STEM and optical spectra [5,13] concluded that in the active catalysts ''0th Cu and Cu1'1" species are present. The Fourier transform of the Cu K-edge EXAFS ofCu33-Zn67 catalyst (33 at% Cu) is shown in fig. 3a. The peaks at 1.39 and 2.25 A were windowed separately and the inverse transform fitted using the phase and amplitude parameters for Cu 0 scattering in Cu^O and Cu Cu scattering in Cu metal. Good fits were obtained using a Cu 0 distance of 1.79 A and a Cu Cu distance of 2.57 A, as shown in figs. 3b and 3c. However, when we extended the window re- 622 0.02 S 0.0' x 0.01 0.00 '-002 2.00 6.00 k (A"') 10.00 0.01 c 01 0 S 0.00 (c) 0.00 4.00 R(A) 800 0.01 - 0.00 -0.0) 3.00 7.00 k (A-1) 11.00 ( & i o.oi 0 *fc-U1 c U 0^, 0 / 0 3^f ' / 0' ; 0S0.00 /Sad A^-A-.- , i 000 4.00 8. R(A) (f) Fig. 1. (a) Fourier transform of the Cu K-edge EXAFS of CuSO-NiSO/AlaOs. (b) Inverse transform of the Cu K-edge EXAFS of Cu50-Ni50/Al203 over the 1.1-2.5 A range (solid curve). Dotted curve is the calculated best fit using Cu-Cu parameters ofCu metal, (c) Fourier transform of the residual spectrum (dotted curve) and the Fourier transform of the solid curve in (b). (d) In- verse transform of the residual spectrum over the 1.2-1.7 A range, (e) Calculated EXAFS using the parameters of Cu-0 in Cu^O and Cu-Cu in Cu metal (dotted curve) and the experimental inverse transform over the 1.1-2.5 A range (solid curve). (0 Fourier transform of the calculated EXAFS of a two-phase model (dotted curve). The solid curve shows the experimental data. Fourier transforms of the Cu K-edge EXAFS of (a) Cu/AlsO,; (c) Cu75-Ni25/Al2<)3; (e) Cu25-Ni75/Al2C>3. The cor- responding inverse transforms (over the R range 1.1 2.5 A) are given by the solid curve in (b), (d) and (0, respectively; the calcu- lated spectra using the parameters of Cu-0 in Cu^O and Cu-Cu in Cu metal are shown by dotted curves. 624 Volume 127, number 6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 4 July 1986 Fig. 3. (a) Fourier transform of the Cu K-edge EXAFS of the Cu-ZnO catalyst (33 at% Cu). (b) Inverse transform over the R range 1.1 to 1.7 A (solid curve) and best fit obtained using parameters of Cu-0 in Cu^O (dotted curve), (c) Inverse transform over the 2.0 to 2.5 A range (solid curve) and best fit obtained using parameters ofCu-Cu in Cu metal (dotted curve), (d) Inverse transform over the 1.1 to 2.5 A range (solid curve) and best fit obtained with a two-phase model using parameters of Cu 0 in Cu^O and Cu-Cu in Cu metal (dotted curve), (e) Inverse transform over the 1.1 to 2.5 A range (solid curve) and best fit obtained using three-phase model (dotted curve). 625 Volume 127, number 6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 4 July 1986 gion to 1.1-2.5 A (fig. 3a) including both the peaks at 1.39 and 2.25 A, the agreement between the experi- mental and calculated (from eq. (2)) spectra (using the parameters of Cu 0 in Cu^O and Cu Cu in Cu metal) was not satisfactory (fig. 3d). The fits obtained in figs. 3b and 3c with the single-phase model for the individual transforms were good because we had ignored the region between 1.7 and 2.0 A (in fig. 3 a) in the analysis and took the windowed peaks at 1.39 and 2.25 A in- dependently. It therefore became apparent that one Cu Cu and one Cu-0 scattering are insufficient to give a good fit for the two-phase analysis in fig. 3d which takes into account the entire region involving the two peaks at 1.39 and 2.25 A. This suggested the presence of a third Cu species. In order to identify the unknown back scatterer, the residual spectrum was ob- tained as the difference between experimental and cal- culated EXAFS (from fig. 3d). The envelope of the residual spectrum indicated that the unknown back scatterer was not oxygen but a heavy scatterer (Cu or Zn). Since the scattering parameters of Cu and Zn are similar, it is difficult to distinguish Cu Cu and Cu Zn scatterers. A three-phase model using an additional Cu Cu(Zn) distance of 2.26 besides that at 2.57 A used earlier and one Cu-0 distance of 1.79 A, gave good agreement between the calculated and experimental data, as shown in fig. 3e. It was possible to rationalise the additional Cu-Cu(Zn) distance of 2.26 A as due to Cu dissolved in ZnO lattice based on earlier litera- ture [5,13]. This species is probably Cu1"1' in a unique site in ZnO. Acknowledgement The authors thank the Department of Science and Technology and University Grants Commission for sup- port of this research. head.ce:title: Analysis of EXAFS data of multiphasic heterogeneous catalysts

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Cu K-edge EXAFS spectra of Cu-Ni/Al2O3 and Cu-ZnO catalysts, both of which contain more than one Cu species, have been analysed making use of an additive relation for the EXAFS function. The analysis, which also makes use of residual spectra for identifying the species, shows good agreement between experimental and calculated spectra.
